article.head: Climate Action Note – State of the climate

text.p: Humanity’s use of fossil fuels has caused a climate emergency - ‘a code red for the planet’ according to UN SG Antonio Guterres. The devastating consequences of the climate emergency are threatening our lives, economy, health and food systems - and extreme weather events are already wrecking havoc across the world. We are far from keeping the global temperature rise safe below 1.5 degrees as promised in the Paris Agreement.
The UNEP Climate Dashboard displays the global state of climate action, major sources, the impact on human health and national efforts to tackle this critical issue.

article.title: Emissions
article.head: GHG emissions are choking our world and changing our climate

text.p: Global temperatures are linked to the concentration of greenhouse gases (GHG) in our atmosphere and we are heading for a catastrophic rise in excess of 3°C this century. To limit this to 1.5°C, as promised in the Paris Agreement, we need to cut emissions by 30 gigatones annually by 2030. That means cutting emissions from transport and industry, managing land and resources more efficiently, building smart cities and curbing deforestation and food waste.

article.title: Per capita
article.head: Our individual carbon footprints vary wildly; wealth is a key factor

text.p: We all emit GHG in the cause of our lives. But some people emit a lot more than others. The world’s wealthiest 1 percent produce more than twice the emissions of the poorest 50 percent. As developing countries grow their economies, they need financial assistance and technical support to transition to low-carbon, resilient strategies. We can reduce emissions while growing the economy. The energy sector alone can cut emissions by 12.5 gigatonnes annually by switching to renewable energy and using its power more efficiently.

article.title: Trends
article.head: Some countries are making progress but all nations need to step up

text.p: In 2019, total GHG emissions, including land-use change, reached a new high of 59.1 GtCO2e. This is far above what is needed to achieve the 2015 Paris Agreement goals of limiting global warming to 1.5°C. Yet the technological solutions already exist, including renewable power, green hydrogen and modern bioenergy. And government subsidies and support could be directed to push towards low-carbon, green policies.

article.title: By country
article.head: Some countries are making progress but all nations need to step up

text.p: In 2019, total GHG emissions, including land-use change, reached a new high of 59.1 GtCO2e. This is far above what is needed to achieve the 2015 Paris Agreement goals of limiting global warming to well below 2°C and pursuing 1.5°C. The good news is that the technologies already exist, including renewable power, green hydrogen and modern bioenergy. The COVID-19 crisis offers a chance to direct recovery measures towards low-carbon, green policies.
